5671.meaning_1: periphery; remote place; somewhere out of the way
5671.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In the context of the DN 25:5.5 sentence, "antamanta" refers specifically to the outer edge or periphery (such as the edge of a pasture where a cow lurks), indicating a place that is remote or marginal, not centrally located.
5671.sutta_1: seyyathāpi nāma gokāṇā pariyantacārinī antamantāneva sevati.
5671.example_1: He’s just like a one-eyed cow, circling around and lurking on the periphery.

5667.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
antapanta in context refers to the most remote or outlying places, often in the sense of seeking seclusion or living at the periphery, as with an ascetic living away from settlements.
5667.example_1: suññāgārahatā samaṇassa gotamassa paññā aparisāvacaro samaṇo gotamo nālaṃ sallāpāya. so antamantāneva sevati [antapantāneva] . seyyathāpi nāma gokāṇā pariyantacārinī antamantāneva sevati.

34378.meaning_1: occurring every two days; (comm) with two days in-between
34378.meaning_2: every two days; subsisting on food every two days
34378.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In the context, dvāhikaṃ āhāraṃ āhāreti refers to taking food every two days as a religious practice; the suffix -ika denotes "pertaining to" or "having the nature of", so dvāhika describes something that recurs in a two-day cycle.
34378.example_1: idha, nigrodha, tapassī acelako hoti muttācāro, hatthāpalekhano [hatthāvalekhano], na ehibhaddantiko, na tiṭṭhabhaddantiko, nābhihaṭaṃ, na uddissakataṃ, na nimantanaṃ sādiyati, so na kumbhimukhā paṭiggaṇhāti, na kaḷopimukhā paṭiggaṇhāti, na eḷakamantaraṃ, na daṇḍamantaraṃ, na musalamantaraṃ, na dvinnaṃ bhuñjamānānaṃ, na gabbhiniyā, na pāyamānāya, na purisantaragatāya, na saṅkittīsu, na yattha sā upaṭṭhito hoti, na yattha makkhikā saṇḍasaṇḍacārinī, na macchaṃ, na maṃsaṃ, na suraṃ, na merayaṃ, na thusodakaṃ pivati, so ekāgāriko vā hoti ekālopiko, dvāgāriko vā hoti dvālopiko, sattāgāriko vā hoti sattālopiko, ekissāpi dattiyā yāpeti, dvīhipi dattīhi yāpeti, sattahipi dattīhi yāpeti, ekāhikampi āhāraṃ āhāreti, dvīhikampi [dvāhikaṃpi] āhāraṃ āhāreti, sattāhikampi āhāraṃ āhāreti, iti evarūpaṃ addhamāsikampi pariyāyabhattabhojanānuyogamanuyutto viharati. so sākabhakkho vā hoti, sāmākabhakkho vā hoti, nīvārabhakkho vā hoti, daddulabhakkho vā hoti, haṭabhakkho vā hoti, kaṇabhakkho vā hoti, ācāmabhakkho vā hoti, piññākabhakkho vā hoti, tiṇabhakkho vā hoti, gomayabhakkho vā hoti, vanamūlaphalāhāro yāpeti pavattaphalabhojī.

12909.meaning_1: makes (someone) desire; makes (someone) wish (for); leads (someone) to expect
12909.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In the sentence, āsīsāpeti means “leads others to expect” or “causes others to wish for,” i.e., inducing hope or desire for a reward through their actions.
12909.sutta_1: na bhāvitamāsīsati, na bhāvitamāsīsāpeti, na bhāvitamāsīsato samanuñño hoti.
12909.example_1: They don’t expect rewards from their practice, they don’t lead others to expect rewards, and they don’t approve of expecting rewards.

12907.meaning_1: desiring; wishing to get; hoping to get; expecting
12907.meaning_2: desiring; wishing to get; expecting (in the sense of expecting results or rewards from an action or practice)
12907.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In the cited context, āsīsanta refers specifically to those who are “expecting” or “hoping to get” something as results or rewards from their practice; the tone is non-approbatory, conveying non-attachment to desired outcomes.
12907.sutta_1: na bhāvitamāsīsati, na bhāvitamāsīsāpeti, na bhāvitamāsīsato samanuñño hoti.
12907.example_1: They don’t expect rewards from their practice, they don’t lead others to expect rewards, and they don’t approve of expecting rewards.

53580.meaning_1: unskilfully; unwisely; in an unwholesome way; wrongly
53580.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
The form yathāakusalena is the indeclinable instrumental compound meaning 'in an unskilful/unwholesome manner', formed with yathā ('as, like') + akusala ('unwholesome, unskilful') + ena (instr. sg. ending, adverbialised). In context, it translates the idea 'it was unskilful/unwholesome of me'.
53580.sutta_1: “saccaṃ, bhante, bhāsitā me esā vācā, yathābālena yathāmūḷhena yathāakusalenā”ti.
53580.example_1: “It’s true, sir, those are my words. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of me.”

34563.meaning_1: provides money; gives finance (to); provides financial support (to)
34563.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In the context of the sentence, dhanamanuppadeti refers to the king granting or providing money, possibly as a reward or incentive, even to those who steal. It indicates the act of supplying funds or financial support.
34563.sutta_1: ‘ye kira, bho, paresaṃ adinnaṃ theyyasaṅkhātaṃ ādiyanti, tesaṃ rājā dhanamanuppadetī’ti.
34563.example_1: ‘It seems the king is providing money to anyone who steals from others!’

4907.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In the DN26 context, anuppadajjeyya refers to the king providing wealth to the poor in his realm; a strong, prescriptive optative meaning: "should provide", "should give out".
4907.example_1: mā ca te, tāta, vijite adhammakāro pavattittha. ye ca te, tāta, vijite adhanā assu, tesañca dhanamanuppadeyyāsi [dhanamanuppadajjeyyāsi] . ye ca te, tāta, vijite samaṇabrāhmaṇā madappamādā paṭiviratā khantisoracce niviṭṭhā ekamattānaṃ damenti, ekamattānaṃ samenti, ekamattānaṃ parinibbāpenti, te kālena kālaṃ upasaṅkamitvā paripuccheyyāsi pariggaṇheyyāsi, kiṃ, bhante, kusalaṃ, kiṃ akusalaṃ, kiṃ sāvajjaṃ, kiṃ anavajjaṃ, kiṃ sevitabbaṃ, kiṃ na sevitabbaṃ, kiṃ me karīyamānaṃ dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāya assa, kiṃ vā pana me karīyamānaṃ dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya assāti?

11597.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
Occurs as aorist 2nd person singular of ādiyati, as in 'did you take (what was not given)?' in the context of theft accusation (DN26). The meaning is specifically 'you took' or 'you stole' in legal/ethical context.
11597.example_1: gahetvā rañño khattiyassa muddhābhisittassa dassesuṃ, ayaṃ, deva, puriso paresaṃ adinnaṃ theyyasaṅkhātaṃ ādiyīti. evaṃ vutte, bhikkhave, rājā khattiyo muddhābhisitto taṃ purisaṃ etadavoca, saccaṃ kira tvaṃ, ambho purisa, paresaṃ adinnaṃ theyyasaṅkhātaṃ ādiyīti [ādiyasīti] ? saccaṃ, devāti.

4908.meaning_1: will give; will offer; will pay
4908.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In the sentence 'mayaṃ panassa sālīnaṃ bhāgaṃ anuppadassāmā’ti', anuppadassati is used in the sense of 'will pay' or 'will hand over (a share)', especially referring to supplying or giving something owed or due (here, a share of rice).
4908.example_1: We shall pay them with a share of rice.’

42353.meaning_1: obstruction of the road; blocking the way; highway robbery
42353.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
The compound refers to the criminal act of waylaying or harming travellers by blocking or exploiting a road. In context (DN 26) it refers to causing trouble or injury on the road, i.e. highway robbery or brigandage.
42353.example_1: sutvāna tesaṃ etadahosi, yaṃnūna mayampi tiṇhāni satthāni kārāpessāma [kārāpeyyāma kārāpeyyāmāti], tiṇhāni satthāni kārāpetvā yesaṃ adinnaṃ theyyasaṅkhātaṃ ādiyissāma, te sunisedhaṃ nisedhessāma, mūlaghaccaṃ karissāma, sīsāni tesaṃ chindissāmāti. te tiṇhāni satthāni kārāpesuṃ, tiṇhāni satthāni kārāpetvā gāmaghātampi upakkamiṃsu kātuṃ, nigamaghātampi upakkamiṃsu kātuṃ, nagaraghātampi upakkamiṃsu kātuṃ, panthaduhanampi [panthadūhanaṃpi] upakkamiṃsu kātuṃ. yesaṃ te adinnaṃ theyyasaṅkhātaṃ ādiyanti, te sunisedhaṃ nisedhenti, mūlaghaccaṃ karonti, sīsāni tesaṃ chindanti.

23549.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
Used in context as “hardness; solidity” of the body, indicating a transition from a less physical, more subtle state to a denser, more material one.
23549.sutta_1: yathā yathā kho te, vāseṭṭha, sattā rasapathaviṃ paribhuñjantā tambhakkhā tadāhārā ciraṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu tathā tathā tesaṃ sattānaṃ rasapathaviṃ paribhuñjantānaṃ kharattañceva kāyasmiṃ okkami, vaṇṇavevaṇṇatā ca paññāyittha.
23549.example_1: But so long as they ate that earth’s nectar, their bodies became more solid and they diverged in appearance;

65947.meaning_2: because of pride in one’s own beauty; as a result of arrogance about appearance
65947.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
The compound denotes the cause of an event due to excessive pride in one’s looks, as in the contextual sentence where the earth’s nectar vanishes because of the vanity of beautiful beings.
65947.example_1: And the vanity of the beautiful ones made the earth’s nectar vanish.

34489.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In context, 'dvemāsa' refers to a period of two months during which a restriction is imposed. Compound of 'dve' (two) and 'māsa' (month); dvandva compound.
34489.sutta_1: ye kho pana, vāseṭṭha, tena samayena sattā methunaṃ dhammaṃ paṭisevanti, te māsampi dvemāsampi na labhanti gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā pavisituṃ.
34489.example_1: The beings who had sex together weren’t allowed to enter a village or town for one or two months.

1851.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In context, aṭṭhāhaṃ means “for eight days”, indicating a specific period for which rice was gathered at once.
1851.sutta_1: atha kho so, vāseṭṭha, satto tassa sattassa diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjamāno sāliṃ āhāsi sakideva aṭṭhāhāya, ‘evampi kira, bho, sādhū’ti.
1851.example_1: So that being, following their example, gathered rice for eight days all at once, thinking: ‘This seems fine.’

77180.meaning_2: reaped; cut off; mown (referring to crops)
77180.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In the sentence, lūnaṃ refers specifically to paddy or rice that has been cut or reaped; it emphasizes that the crop has been harvested and did not regrow.
77180.sutta_1: lūnampi nappaṭivirūḷhaṃ, apadānaṃ paññāyittha, saṇḍasaṇḍā sālayo aṭṭhaṃsu.
77180.example_1: it didn’t grow back after reaping, leaving a trace showing, and the rice stood in clumps.

52511.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
māssu is a sandhi of 'mā' (prohibitive particle: don't) + 'ssu' (emphatic particle), giving a strong prohibitive force. In the context, it functions as a direct prohibition: 'Do not (do this again)!'
52511.example_1: Do not do such a thing again.’

18117.meaning_1: did such a thing; performed such an action
18117.meaning_2: acted in such a way; did like this
18117.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
The form evarūpamakāsi means 'did such a thing', reflecting the sense in the contextual sentence 'Do not do such a thing again.' It is a compound of 'evarūpaṃ' (such a form/thing) and 'akāsi' (did). Used to refer to repeating an act performed previously.
18117.example_1: Do not do such a thing again.’

51718.meaning_1: elected by the people; democratically chosen
51718.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In context (dn27:21.1), 'mahājanasammata' refers to someone who is 'elected by the people', specifically identifying the first king as chosen by popular consensus; the compound is formed as an instrumental tappurisa, meaning 'one agreed to by the people' (mahājanena).
51718.sutta_1: mahājanasammatoti kho, vāseṭṭha, ‘mahāsammato, mahāsammato’ tveva paṭhamaṃ akkharaṃ upanibbattaṃ.
51718.example_1: ‘Elected by the people’, Vāseṭṭha, is the meaning of ‘elected one’, the first term applied to them.

54488.meaning_1: to please; to delight; to make happy
54488.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In the context of dn27:21.3, 'rañjeti' indicates the action of pleasing or delighting others; the king is described as one who pleases others (with principle). This is the causative form of the root rañj (to take delight), meaning 'to cause to take delight' or 'to please.'
54488.sutta_1: dhammena pare rañjetīti kho, vāseṭṭha, ‘rājā, rājā’ tveva tatiyaṃ akkharaṃ upanibbattaṃ.
54488.example_1: ‘They please others with principle’ is the meaning of ‘king’, the third term applied to them.

67061.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In context (dn27:22.5), 'vāhenti' is used causatively with mental objects, meaning 'they set aside' or 'remove' bad, unskillful things; hence vāheti here has the specific sense of 'removing' or 'setting aside', not just physical conveyance.
67061.sutta_1: pāpake akusale dhamme vāhentīti kho, vāseṭṭha, ‘brāhmaṇā, brāhmaṇā’ tveva paṭhamaṃ akkharaṃ upanibbattaṃ.
67061.example_1: ‘They set aside bad, unskillful things’ is the meaning of ‘brahmin’, the first term applied to them.

28963.meaning_1: successfully completes the method; succeeds in completing that system
28963.meaning_2: achieves the right method; attains the correct system
28963.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
The verb means "to succeed in the right method/system", emphasizing the successful completion of a particular process or training, as in the DN 29 context where a practitioner is said to achieve a systematic method.
28963.example_1: ‘Clearly the venerable is practicing systematically and will succeed in that system.’

17650.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In the context, ekasatthar refers specifically to the Buddha comparing himself to all other teachers; here it emphasizes the sense of “not even a single teacher (other than myself)” having attained such success and renown.
17650.sutta_1: yāvatā kho, cunda, etarahi satthāro loke uppannā, nāhaṃ, cunda, aññaṃ ekasatthārampi samanupassāmi evaṃlābhaggayasaggappattaṃ yatharivāhaṃ.
17650.example_1: Of all the teachers in the world today, Cunda, I don’t see even a single one who has reached the peak of material things and fame like me.

30124.meaning_1: blade (of a weapon); flat surface; plane
30124.meaning_2: blade; flat of a blade; surface
30124.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In the cited DN 29:16.11 context, 'tala' refers to the flat surface or blade of a razor, as opposed to its sharp edge. The sense is specifically 'blade' or 'flat surface' of a razor or tool, which differs from other meanings like 'palm' or 'sole'.
30124.sutta_1: khurassa sādhunisitassa talamassa passati, dhārañca khvassa na passati.
30124.example_1: You can see the blade of a well-sharpened razor, but not the edge.

48734.meaning_1: well-versed in the letter; skilled in expression; knowledgeable in phrasing
48734.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In the context “atthupetaṃ byañjanupetan’ti” (dn29:21.7), the term signals someone accomplished both in the meaning (attha) and in accurate, proper, or elegant expression (byañjana) of it; it expresses accomplishment in the letter/form as a complement to the sense/meaning.
48734.sutta_1: ye mayaṃ āyasmantaṃ tādisaṃ sabrahmacāriṃ passāma evaṃ atthupetaṃ byañjanupetan’ti.
48734.example_1: to see a venerable such as yourself, so well-versed in the meaning and the phrasing, as one of our spiritual companions!’

1554.meaning_1: having a different perception; perceiving otherwise; with different opinions
1554.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
This compound describes beings who perceive or consider things differently from others, as in the referenced Sutta passage. The kammadhāraya construction indicates "one whose perception is otherwise".
1554.example_1: Because there are beings who have different opinions on this topic.

38837.meaning_1: neither material nor formless; neither with form nor formless
38837.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In DN 29 this adjective describes an attā (self/being) that is neither material (with form) nor formless, thus negating both material and immaterial conceptions of self.

4226.meaning_2: untroubled; without cause for distress; not marked by danger
4226.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In the given context (dn30:1.5.5), 'animitta' describes land that is 'untroubled' or 'free from sign of danger.' The sense focuses less on abstract or meditative 'signlessness', and more on the absence of threats, disruptions, or markers of danger.
4226.sutta_1: so imaṃ pathaviṃ sāgarapariyantaṃ akhilamanimittamakaṇṭakaṃ iddhaṃ phītaṃ khemaṃ sivaṃ nirabbudaṃ adaṇḍena asatthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhāvasati.
4226.example_1: After conquering this land girt by sea—free of harassment by bandits, successful and prosperous, safe, blessed, and untroubled—he reigns by principle, without rod or sword.

11282.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In the context of DN30, samattam ācari (samantam ācari) means “performed (it) completely; thoroughly fulfilled”. The verb expresses the successful completion or carrying out of wholesome actions and conduct.
11282.example_1:
sacce ca dhamme ca dame ca saṃyame,
soceyyasīlālayuposathesu ca,
dāne ahiṃsāya asāhase rato,
daḷhaṃ samādāya samattamācari [samantamācari].

58641.meaning_1: with all the trimmings; together with all its (necessary or fitting) accessories or constituents; furnished with all accessories
58641.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In context, saparivāra means “with all the trimmings”, i.e. giving a gift not alone, but complete with appropriate accessories, furniture, or items that are needed together. The sense broadens from “with an entourage” to “with all fittings; fully equipped (esp. for a gift)”.
58641.sutta_1: bahujanassa sukhāvaho ahosi, ubbegauttāsabhayaṃ apanuditā, dhammikañca rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṃ saṃvidhātā, saparivārañca dānaṃ adāsi.
58641.example_1: He conveyed happiness to many people, eliminating threats, terror, and danger, providing just protection and security, and giving gifts with all the trimmings.

52382.meaning_1: danger of death and slaughter; fear of being killed or murdered
52382.meaning_2: horror or fear of death and execution; peril of being subjected to killing
52382.compound_construction: māraṇa ca vadha ca bhaya ca
52382.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In context (dn30:1.12.2), the compound refers to the personal realization of the fear or terror experienced in facing fatal violence or mortal peril, including both killing (vadhā) and general danger to life (māraṇa). The context emphasizes a deep awareness of existential threat.
52382.example_1: “Realizing for himself the horrors of death,

51476.meaning_1: danger of death and killing; fear of death or being killed
51476.meaning_2: danger of death or execution; threat of being killed
51476.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
This compound refers to the combined threat of death (maraṇa) or being killed (vadha). In the DN30 context, it means recognizing the risk to one's own life (from any cause or violence), which leads a person to abstain from killing others out of empathy or self-preservation.
51476.example_1:
māraṇavadhabhayattano [maraṇavadhabhayattano,
maraṇavadhabhayamattano] viditvā,
paṭivirato paraṃ māraṇāyahosi,
tena sucaritena saggamagamā [tena so sucaritena saggamagamāsi],
sukataphalavipākamanubhosi.

52379.meaning_2: killing; the act of killing; taking life
52379.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In the contextual sentence, māraṇa refers to refraining from the act of killing living beings, i.e. abstaining from taking life.
52379.example_1: he refrained from killing other creatures.

23296.meaning_1: solid food; eatable; chewable and edible
23296.meaning_lit: that which is to be eaten and chewed
23296.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In context, “khajjabhojjamatha leyya sāyiyaṃ,” refers specifically to the best of flavors, highlighting “khajjabhojja” as solid eatable foods (chewables and eatables) distinguished from drinkables and lickables, thus in a compound sense: “things to be eaten and chewed.”
23296.example_1: “He used to give the very best of flavors—

70853.meaning_2: tenderness of hands and feet; delicacy of hands and feet
70853.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In the context (dn30:1.15.7), "hatthapādamudutā" refers to the characteristic of having soft and tender hands and feet, one of the marks of a great person (mahāpurisalakkhaṇa).
70853.example_1: and tender hands and feet are found.

23298.meaning_1: who gets various tasty kinds of food; obtaining every kind of delicious food
23298.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
Used in DN 30 to mean someone who gains the highest variety of delicious foods; denotes the recipient of every kind of eatable (khajja) and consumable (bhojja) with taste (rasa).
23298.example_1: supreme in gaining tasty foods of all sorts,

58810.meaning_1: who has severed all bonds to the household life; who has cut all ties to lay-life
58810.meaning_2: one who cuts through all the bonds of lay/householder existence; one who has broken free from all household constraints
58810.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
Used of someone who has completely relinquished household bonds; contextually describes one who has gone forth, cutting all fetters of householder life (see dn30:1.15.13).
58810.example_1: cutting all bonds of the lay life.’”

2638.meaning_1: beneficial conduct; acting for one's own best interest; action for one's own good
2638.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In context (dn30:1.18.2), 'atthacariyatā' refers to conduct (cariya) which benefits oneself (attha), i.e., living for one's own good or acting for one's self-interest (in a positive moral sense).

46223.meaning_1: kind words; endearing speech; speaking kindly
46223.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In the context from DN 30, piyavāditaṃ refers to speaking kindly or using affectionate words as a means of showing equal and friendly treatment toward others.

59693.meaning_1: fact of having similar interests; (contextually) state of sharing the same desire
59693.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In the context of DN30, samānachandatā refers to the virtue of having harmonious intentions or interests with others (such as in community living or cooperation). Used with piyavāditā and samānattatā, it highlights shared goodwill and collaborative spirit.
59693.example_1:
dānampi catthacariyatañca [dānampi ca atthacariyatampi ca],
piyavāditañca samānattatañca [piyavadatañca samānachandatañca],
kariyacariyasusaṅgahaṃ bahūnaṃ,
anavamatena guṇena yāti saggaṃ.

20442.meaning_2: tenderness of hands and feet; delicacy of hands and feet
20442.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In the contextual sentence (dn30:1.18.7), 'karacaraṇamudutā' refers to the special physical characteristic of the baby prince, indicating that his hands and feet possessed extraordinary softness or tenderness—a mark of a great being according to ancient texts.

65588.meaning_1: acting according to what one says; complying with instruction; responsive to commands
65588.meaning_2: obedient; following what is told; responding to words or speech
65588.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1
In the context of dn30:1.18.16, vacanapaṭikara refers to those who listen carefully and act in accordance with the leader's (or teacher's) words and instructions—demonstrating responsiveness or obedience.
65588.example_1: Devoted, they respond to his words;
